title: 106_hr5432
content: The Act is titled the "Nazi War Crimes and Japanese Imperial Government Disclosure Act". Congress adopted the Nazi War Crimes Disclosure Act in 1998, requiring the executive branch to identify and declassify records related to Nazi war crimes. The Interagency Group has screened over 600 million pages, declassified 1.5 million pages, and made them accessible to the public at the National Archives. The Interagency Group, despite limited resources, has declassified millions of pages related to Nazi war crimes. Significant new information about the Holocaust has been revealed, but further progress depends on adequate staff support and funding. Congress has not allocated funds for the Interagency Group's operations. The Interagency Group, lacking resources, struggles to review and understand the significance of released materials related to Nazi war crimes. The Nazi War Crimes Disclosure Act mandates the review of records pertaining to World War II, including those involving the Nazi and Japanese Imperial Governments. The Interagency Group returned over 18,000,000 pages of Japanese records to Japan as requested. To comply with the Nazi War Crimes Disclosure Act, the Japanese Government's cooperation is needed to review and release World War II records efficiently. The Interagency Group is working diligently under the Act's three-year authorization but requires more time for completion. The Interagency Group is struggling to complete the review of Japanese records under the Nazi War Crimes Disclosure Act due to time constraints. The authority of the Nazi War Criminal Records Interagency Working Group is extended and modified to include Japanese Imperial Government records. Amendment to the Nazi War Crimes Disclosure Act includes changing the title to include Japanese Imperial Government, extending the authority from 3 to 5 years, increasing the membership to include 4 public members, and adding functions related to Japanese Imperial Government records. The amendment to the Nazi War Crimes Disclosure Act includes adding a definition for Japanese Imperial Government records, which are classified records related to individuals involved in persecution based on race, gender, religion, national origin, or political opinion. The amendment to the Nazi War Crimes Disclosure Act adds a definition for Japanese Imperial Government records related to persecution based on race, gender, religion, national origin, or political opinion during a specific period under various entities associated with the Japanese Imperial Army or Government. The Nazi War Crimes Disclosure Act includes a presumption of public interest in releasing records of Nazi war criminals or Japanese Imperial Government records. The exemption can only be used if disclosure would harm a specific interest, as determined by the agency head. Any such determination must be reported to relevant congressional committees. The exemptions in the Nazi War Crimes Disclosure Act can only be used to exempt records if disclosure would harm a specific interest, as determined by the agency head. Any such determination must be reported to relevant congressional committees. Amendments to the Act include defining 'Japanese Imperial Government records'. Amendments to the Nazi War Crimes Disclosure Act include adding 'Japanese Imperial Government records' to the definition of records. This change is reflected in various sections of the Act. Amendments to the Nazi War Crimes Disclosure Act include authorizing appropriations of $5,000,000 for fiscal years 2001, 2002, and 2003, changing the records timeframe from January 1, 1931, to September 2, 1945, and modifying the name of the Interagency Group to include Japanese Imperial Government records. The Nazi War Crimes Disclosure Act has been amended to establish an interagency working group for Nazi war crimes and Japanese Imperial Government records. The Act now requires disclosure and expedited processing of FOIA requests for these records. Additionally, a report on the activities of the interagency working group is mandated. The Nazi War Crimes and Japanese Imperial Government Interagency Working Group must submit a report to Congress within one year of the Act's enactment. The report will detail the activities of the Interagency Group and applicable Federal agencies, including records processed and their disposition. Congress committees specified for review include the Committee on the Judiciary and the Select Committee on Intelligence of the Senate. The Committee on the Judiciary, Government Reform and Oversight, and Intelligence of the House of Representatives are involved in oversight. The House of Representatives committees oversee the cooperation of foreign nations, especially Japan, in providing records to the Nazi War Crimes and Japanese Imperial Government Records Interagency Working Group.
